United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
February 12, 1982.
James Pilafian, Miami, Fla., for debtor/defendant.
Elliott Miller, Miami Beach, Fla., for plaintiff.

ORDER DENYING MOTION FOR ATTORNEY'S FEES
THOMAS C. BRITTON, Bankruptcy Judge.
The debtor and his attorney seek assessment of $4,000 costs and attorney's fees against the plaintiff creditor on the ground that plaintiff sued to block his discharge under 11 U.S.C. § 727(a)(2)(A) [fraudulent transfer] and (4)(A) [false oath] and lost. (C.P. No. 14). The motion was heard on February 8.
The debtor wants $500 "costs", which is the sum he paid his attorney for representing him in this action. The attorney values his services between August, 1981, and now *101 in defending this adversary proceeding, which was not filed until October 30, 1981 and was dismissed on December 16, at $4,000. He estimates that he spent 65 hours on the matter. The application has been opposed on the ground that it is excessive. However, I do not reach that question because I conclude that there is no basis to assess attorney's fees in this case.
